body: Great, thanks for getting this in motion.  I'll start digging into it.

Re pykernel removal: Am I right that pykernel was our pure-Python kernel, without all the IPython secret sauce? Is there something similar that replaces it? It strikes me as potentially useful, both as an easy to understand example, and as a Python execution server for non-interactive use.

It's removed for a few reasons:
- it s ~never used
- it is frequently broken
- it fails to comply with the message spec quite a bit
- it is almost entirely duplicate code of ipkernel

For use as an example, one can always find it in 0.12.
OK, that's fair enough.
references removed to pykernel from Qt and KernelApp
#1647 revealed an issue in streamkernel, which would necessarily conflict quite severely with this, as that file has been removed.  So a fix for that is now included.

**Test results for commit c1a2747 merged into master**
Platform: darwin
- python2.6: OK (libraries not available: matplotlib pymongo qt tornado wx wx.aui)
- python2.7: OK
- python3.2: Failed, log at https://gist.github.com/2631856 (libraries not available: matplotlib pymongo qt tornado wx wx.aui)

Not available for testing: python3.1

The test does seem to be correctly picking up a stray reference to `streamkernel` - I don't know why it only appears on Python 3.

https://github.com/minrk/ipython/blob/0c2728a924dcb7bdcbddb07f40ca7545186ee1a5/IPython/parallel/apps/ipengineapp.py#L47
Indeed, apparently I messed up a bit in my last rebase.

**Test results for commit fc1af3c merged into master**
Platform: darwin
- python2.6: OK (libraries not available: matplotlib pymongo qt tornado wx wx.aui)
- python2.7: OK
- python3.2: Failed, log at https://gist.github.com/2639226

Not available for testing: python3.1
I don't know what's happening with that test failure - it looks like the file was installed without 2to3 having run.
Yes, I will make a PR against test_pr to fix that.  Python 3.2 is re-using the build dir from 2.7, so it skips a bunch of 2to3 and I have to `rm -rf build` between builds.
OK - I wonder why I don't see that. Maybe a Linux/Mac difference, but I'm not sure quite how.
Yes, I think it is.  The build dir gets a 3.2 suffix on Linux, but not on OS X.  Only seems to affect pure-Python packages.

Not available for testing:

A few more issues have been identified and fixed along the way:
- embed_kernel (#1738) had issues with being able to be re-used like embed
- displaypub output is now tracked by the Client in the `outputs` list in metadata objects

**Test results for commit f04ffba merged into master**
Platform: linux2
- python2.7: OK (libraries not available: pymongo wx wx.aui)
- python3.2: OK (libraries not available: matplotlib pymongo qt wx wx.aui)

Not available for testing:

From my usage, this is looking very solid, and fixes a ton of important problems.  It's a lot of code, but on first read it looks very good and with good test coverage.  Great job, Min.  I'll try to dig in a bit more and will continue using this branch for a couple of days also.

Some other changes not discussed in the comments:
- serialization code moved from parallel.util into zmq.serialize
- remove parallel-specific `asbytes()` in favor of general utils from py3compat, which was written later.
- include `@interactive` decorator in top-level IPython.parallel namespace, where it belongs.
- execute_replies are wrapped in an ExecuteReply object, which organizes the outputs/pyout, etc.

Running even the simplest code `a=10` in the Notebook causes the following to be printed to the terminal where the notebook server was started:

`
[NotebookApp] Malformed message: ['<IDS|MSG>', '079b7ae2dd769a95b54522461d4219ef', 
'{"username":"kernel","engine":"8e2f451e-4760-4250-9c2d-1e04fc402b3f",
"msg_type":"execute_reply","dependencies_met":true,"msg_id":"c39c126d-cf61-4651-b37e-d1405bec4cfa",
"started":"2012-05-21T21:15:32.535135","session":"ab5f4727-968e-486a-a44f-d947e00c9f88","status":"ok",
"date":"2012-05-21T21:15:32.538863"}', 
'{"username":"username","msg_id":"CE89F40C9BE14B84B054276209577CF6","msg_type":"execute_request",
"session":"74A3FBC0158F4C018362D24381479AF1"}', '{"status":"ok","execution_count":1,
"user_variables":{},"payload":[],"user_expressions":{}}']
`

This is coming from the notebook's `handlers.py` in `reserialize_reply`, which cleans the message to make it JSON safe.  Did something about the message format change?

Currently, `%pylab` and `%pylab inline` work fine in a regular Notebook kernel, but don't seem to work in an engine kernel.  @fperez and I were talking today and think that `%pylab` should be supported in the engine.  When I try:

`dv.execute('%pylab inline')
`

I get an exception on the engines with an error message of "MultipleInstanceError: Multiple incompatible subclass instances of IPKernelApp are being created".

The notebook error you are seeing is a bug in reserialize_reply, which I will fix.  It neglected the datetime serialization we use everywhere else.  I will also fix the logging in the notebook, which unhelpfully suppresses error messages, replacing them with useless generic statements.

notebook bug is fixed, and `%pylab` and plotting definitely works in an Engine. eventloop messages are now INFO-level.

Getting embed_kernel to work in an Engine will be trickier, because it breaks the fundamental singleton nature of Applications. (IPEngineApp and IPKernelApp must run simultaneously).

I am trying to test the plotting on the engines and can't quite seem to get there.  I have run `%pylab inline` on the engines and the `plot(range(10))` using `execute`.  When I look at the `ExecuteReply` from each engine though there is no data for the plot.  I feel like I am missing something.  What is the best way to see the plot data from the engines?

I guess I was hoping that it can see that there is already a kernel
running in the engine and just use that existing one.

On Tue, May 22, 2012 at 12:56 AM, Min RK
reply@reply.github.com
wrote:

> notebook bug is fixed, and `%pylab` and plotting definitely works in an Engine. eventloop messages are now INFO-level.
> 
> Getting embed_kernel to work in an Engine will be trickier, because it breaks the fundamental singleton nature of Applications. (IPEngineApp and IPKernelApp must run simultaneously).
> 
> ---
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/1630#issuecomment-5841423

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

> I guess I was hoping that it can see that there is already a kernel
> running in the engine and just use that existing one.

I actually have an idea for this that should be simple enough (skip the IPKernelApp bit entirely).  I think we are seeing that Kernel should probably have been a SingletonConfigurable.

I see two options here:
1. embed_kernel as it is elsewhere (inject into calling scope).
2. turning an engine into a kernel (essentially adding a few `bind` calls, on existing sockets), but with the same namespace.

The difficulty in 1. is in restoring the original namespace after the embed call leaves, and making the embed call block properly (it wouldn't).  I think I can do 2. with little difficulty.

I've implemented case 2., where embed_kernel called from an Engine will expose the engine as a regular Kernel.  What it will NOT do is embed in the calling scope.  It's easy enough to do this, but what I don't know how to do is get back to the original scope when the embedding is done.

I also had to finally fix the `init_logging` in the Application, which was a bit of a mess, and causes problems when creating multiple Application objects.  I moved that code into `Application._log_default`, where it belonged in the first place.

I think this branch is looking pretty good.  I have used the notebook, qtconsole and engines some and everything seems to be working as expected.  I have also tried to skim through the code (almost line by line).  This is enough code that at some point we just need to merge, have people start to use it and find any remaining bugs that show up.

The only other thing we have talked about that I don't see yet is the separate `promote_to_kernel` function.
